title: Financial Adviser Pleads Guilty to Facilitating Bribes in Ecuador
text:
The U.S. Department of Justice flag flies outside its headquarters in Washington, D.C. The Justice Department said a financial adviser based in Miami pleaded guilty to a money laundering conspiracy.

A financial adviser based in Miami pleaded guilty to participating in a scheme that involved paying nearly $3 million in bribes to officials at a state-owned oil company in Ecuador, federal prosecutors said Friday.

Frank Roberto Chatburn Ripalda, 42, pleaded guilty in a federal court in Miami to one count of conspiracy to commit money laundering. Mr. Chatburn played a role in promoting violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and bribery laws in Ecuador, the U.S. Justice Department said.

A lawyer for Mr. Chatburn didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment.

Newsletter Sign-up Mr. Chatburn played a central role in setting up a scheme to bribe former officials at Petroecuador, a state-owned and state-controlled oil company, according to prosecutors. While serving as a financial adviser to an unnamed oil-services contractor, Mr. Chatburn agreed to make the illicit payments, which he funneled through shell companies and bank accounts in the U.S., Panama, the Cayman Islands, Curaçao and Switzerland, according to prosecutors. He also created Panamanian shell companies with Swiss bank accounts for the Petroecuador officials involved in the scheme, prosecutors said. Mr. Chatburn is scheduled to be sentenced on Dec. 18. Write to Kristin Broughton at kristin.broughton@wsj.com
